lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six body parts (arms, hands, fingers, legs, feet, toes) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show body part flashcards (arms, legs, toes, etc.). Say each word and have students touch the part on their body or in the SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Call-and-Move Challenge❞ – After naming each body part (“arms,” “legs,” etc.), challenge students to create a silly action that uses that part (e.g., wiggle your fingers, flap your arms). Then, have students give each other a movement instruction using full sentences:
“I’ve got long arms! Flap your arms!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about body parts using “I’ve got…” and an adjective.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Say: “I’ve got long arms.” Write it on the board. Students repeat and point to their own arms. Then practise with other body parts.
stretchStrategies: ❝Call-and-Move Challenge❞ – After naming each body part (“arms,” “legs,” etc.), challenge students to create a silly action that uses that part (e.g., wiggle your fingers, flap your arms). Then, have students give each other a movement instruction using full sentences:
“I’ve got long arms! Flap your arms!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “I’ve got ___.” to describe body parts.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write sentence frame: “I’ve got ___.” Students choose a body part from the board and say a sentence aloud using correct structure.
stretchStrategies: ❝Call-and-Move Challenge❞ – After naming each body part (“arms,” “legs,” etc.), challenge students to create a silly action that uses that part (e.g., wiggle your fingers, flap your arms). Then, have students give each other a movement instruction using full sentences:
